Ideal candidates will have strong quantitative/analytic skills in biology, toxicology, natural resources, environmental sciences or a closely This laboratory based program, under the direction of Dr. related field, and have demonstrated leadership skills in a research context.
title: Environmental Protection Agency Breast Cancer Basic National Health and Environmental Effects Research Laboratory Science Research Mid-Continent Ecology Division Duluth, Minnesota Associate Professor The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is recruiting to fill the position of Supervisory Biologist/Toxicologist/Environmental Scientist, GS-0401/0415/1301-14/15. This vacancy is for the Chief of the Ecotoxicology Analysis Research Branch The Cardinal Bernardin Cancer Center of Loyola at the National Health and Environmental Effects Research Laboratory’s Mid-University Medical Center, under the leadership of Drs. Continent Ecology Division in Duluth, Minnesota. The branch chief provides

Nickoloff as scientific and administrative leadership for the branch, which is engaged in environmental toxicological research. Research foci include biologically based Deputy Director, is seeking outstanding candidates to fill toxicokinetic and toxicodynamic modeling, species and dose extrapolation, a faculty position at the Associate Professor level within chemical bioavailability, mixtures and multiple stressors, avian toxicology, our Breast Cancer Basic Science Program. Candidates population response, contaminated sediments, and other issues relevant to the interpreting and predicting the environmental effects of toxic chemicals. must have developed an innovative research program, This branch is a focal point for delivery of ecotoxicology databases and toxiand demonstrate a strong publication and funding track cological modeling approaches to EPA and to the States

author.particle: citizenship is required. Candidates must meet U.S. Office of Personnel Management qualifications

Science Program highly successful Postdoctoral and Predoctoral training programs, and a major c/o Maggie Storti meeting center, featuring courses and conferences centered around the mouse as a model for human development and disease.
